column5: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects focus#Comma impulse control#Comma and hyperactivity. If you or someone you know has ADHD#Comma seeking professional evaluation and guidance can lead to effective management strategies.

You're not alone. Managing ADHD involves learning coping skills#Comma developing routines#Comma and using tools like planners. Medication and therapy can also be beneficial in helping you thrive with ADHD.

Dealing with distractions can be challenging. Practice techniques like breaking tasks into smaller steps#Comma using timers#Comma and creating an organized workspace. A mental health professional can help you tailor strategies to your specific needs.

Managing impulsivity is possible. Practice mindfulness#Comma pause before making decisions#Comma and seek therapy to address impulsive behaviors. Remember#Comma small changes in habits can make a big difference in managing ADHD symptoms.
